description: From Middle English grand, grond, graund, graunt, from Anglo-Norman graunt, from Old French grant, from Latin grandis. Doublet of grande and grandee.

adjectives.description: grand (comparative grander or more grand, superlative grandest or most grand)

definitionGroups.group: (augmentative) Large, senior (high-ranking), intense, extreme, or exceptional

entries.meaning: Of a large size or extent; great.
Great in size, and fine or imposing in appearance or impression; illustrious, dignified, magnificent.
examples: His simple vision has transformed into something far more grand.

entries.meaning: Having higher rank or more dignity, size, or importance than other persons or things of the same name.
examples: The Grand Viziers of the Ottoman Empire.

entries.meaning: (usually in compound forms) Standing in the second or some more remote degree of parentage or descent (see grand-).
(Ireland, Northern England, colloquial, otherwise dated) Fine; lovely.
examples: A cup of tea? That'd be grand.

entries.meaning: (music) Containing all the parts proper to a given form of composition.
(plural "grand") A thousand of some unit of currency, such as dollars or pounds. (Compare G.)
examples: For quotations using this term, see Citations:grand.

description: From granddaughter, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, etc.

examples: Once, in Maryland, he met four families of slaves who had all been together for a hundred years: great-grands, grands, mothers, fathers, aunts, uncles, cousins, children.
